title: How to Make Easy Enchilada Sauce

steps.headline: Melt one stick butter or margarine in a saucepan on medium heat.
Add tablespoons of flour, a little at a time.
steps.description: You may not need to add as much flour in order to make a loose paste.

steps.headline: Add water, along with ground chili powder and ground cumin.
Bring to a low boil, just long enough to thicken the sauce.
steps.description: If it seems a bit too thick for your needs, it can be thinned further with more water.

steps.headline: Serve!
steps.description: When the sauce is to the taste and consistency that you prefer, it is now ready to pour over rolled and filled tortillas, or used with any other Mexican dish you like.

steps.headline: In a large saucepan or pot, heat olive oil and gently sauté onions and garlic.
steps.description: Onions and garlic should be translucent, not burnt.

steps.headline: While onions and garlic  sauté, combine tomatillos, green peppers, jalapeno peppers, and cilantro in a blender or food processor.
steps.description: If ingredients do not blend well, add a little chicken stock to aid the process.

steps.headline: Pour the tomatillo mixture over the onions and garlic in the saucepan.
To the saucepan, add chicken broth, salt, pepper, and cumin.
Turn burner to high until mixture starts to boil, then turn down to low.
steps.description: Let simmer for 15 minutes to an hour.

steps.headline: In a large saucepan or pot, heat olive oil and gently sauté garlic for 1 minute.
To the garlic, add the rest of the ingredients, except the water.
steps.description: Add the onion, oregano, chili powder, basil, ground black pepper, salt, cumin, parsley, salsa and tomato sauce.

steps.headline: Mix ingredients together and then add the water.
Bring to a boil, then let simmer for 15 minutes to an hour.

text: White Enchilada Sauce Melt one stick butter or margarine in a saucepan on medium heat.  Add tablespoons of flour, a little at a time. You may not need to add as much flour in order to make a loose paste. Add water, along with ground chili powder and ground cumin.  Bring to a low boil, just long enough to thicken the sauce. If it seems a bit too thick for your needs, it can be thinned further with more water. Serve! When the sauce is to the taste and consistency that you prefer, it is now ready to pour over rolled and filled tortillas, or used with any other Mexican dish you like. Green Enchilada Sauce In a large saucepan or pot, heat olive oil and gently sauté onions and garlic. Onions and garlic should be translucent, not burnt. While onions and garlic  sauté, combine tomatillos, green peppers, jalapeno peppers, and cilantro in a blender or food processor. If ingredients do not blend well, add a little chicken stock to aid the process. Pour the tomatillo mixture over the onions and garlic in the saucepan.  To the saucepan, add chicken broth, salt, pepper, and cumin.  Turn burner to high until mixture starts to boil, then turn down to low. Let simmer for 15 minutes to an hour. Serve!  Red Enchilada Sauce In a large saucepan or pot, heat olive oil and gently sauté garlic for 1 minute.  To the garlic, add the rest of the ingredients, except the water. Add the onion, oregano, chili powder, basil, ground black pepper, salt, cumin, parsley, salsa and tomato sauce. Mix ingredients together and then add the water.  Bring to a boil, then let simmer for 15 minutes to an hour.  Serve!
